thread.title: Seven’s a crowd for Raptors’ big men
thread.title_full: Seven’s a crowd for Raptors’ big men | Toronto Star

author: Doug Smith
title: Seven’s a crowd for Raptors’ big men
text:
Dwane Casey has a bigs problem.
As the NBA pre-season enters the homestretch — there are a little more than two weeks until the start of real games, and there are only four pre-season games to go —the Raptors coach is still trying to make sense of a crowded frontcourt situation.
He has anywhere from four to seven players who can lay claim to one of two spots and that’s far too many, leaving him to decide on a workable number relatively quickly.
The obvious choices would seem easy with Jonas Valanciunas and Bismack Biyombo in the middle and Luis Scola and Patrick Patterson at what’s historically been known as the power forward position, but it’s not as simple as throwing two of the four out there and letting them go to work.
“We’re still evaluating everything,” Casey said after the Raptors had about a three-hour work session at the Air Canada Centre on Saturday.
“We’re evaluating all of our rotations with the bigs, who plays well with who, the production we get from who in that foursome.
“It’s important to see who plays well with JV, it’s important to see who plays well with Bismack. Now you’ve got Anthony Bennett playing well. James (Johnson) hasn’t been able to do much because of injury and now he’s coming out of mothballs.
“We’ve got some guys we want to look at in those rotations, not only the first unit but most importantly the second unit.”
To the casual observer, there would seem to be all kinds of time to figure it out but it’s more complex than some would think. The Raptors need to a better rebounding team — a key role for big men — and finding some kind of scoring balance is equally important.
Does Patterson stretch the floor well enough to make Valanciunas a better low post threat or does Patterson work better as a primary scorer next to the offensively-challenged Biyombo?
Can Scola’s smarts mean the ball will move more quickly and decisively if he’s on the court with Kyle Lowry and DeMar DeRozan, or does he lack the court-spacing skills of Patterson?
Lots to work on.
“(Casey) thinks about that a lot more than we do — we just try to play — but I feel everybody kind of feels a little out of place and things will get to normal soon,” Scola said.
Patterson, to many the presumptive starter once Amir Johnson left, is the best shooter of the bunch but he hasn’t provided an awful lot of production in any of Toronto’s three pre-season games. Maybe he’s just getting used to the role, maybe he’s a chronic slow-starting veteran, but the Raptors need his production.
“Pat’s a shooter,” Casey said. “He’s got one thing to do, he shouldn’t be thinking about anything else, that’s who he is. He’s one of the best shooters in the league and that’s what he has to do.
“That’s what all our shooters have to do, shoot the ball. They have the green light.”
That could be the one thing that ignites the offence, some long-range shooting to loosen up defences. The Raptors haven’t been effective from long range so far and it’s a point of emphasis for the coach.
“Not just to shoot it, but it gives the offence a rhythm,” Casey said. “Guys understand where the shots are coming from, who’s expected to shoot. And when you don’t, your spacing’s bad, you’re driving back into traffic. A lot of bad things happen when three-point shooters don’t take their shots.”
Now they just have to figure out who’s on the court to take them.
“We’re evaluating a lot of things, not only positions but the rotation,” Casey said.
